description.level3: Pieces of old viruses that got stuck in our DNA long ago.
description.level4: DNA from viruses that infected our ancestors millions of years ago and became part of our genome.
description.level5: Remnants of retroviruses that inserted themselves into our ancestors' DNA millions of years ago.
description.level6: Human Endogenous Retroviruses (HERVs) are viral sequences integrated into our genome through ancient infections.
description.level7: HERVs are retroviral sequences that integrated into the germline of ancestral primates and were inherited vertically.
description.level8: Human Endogenous Retroviruses represent ~8% of the genome, derived from exogenous retroviral infections that integrated into germline cells.

description.level3: Bits of DNA that can copy themselves and move to new spots.
description.level4: DNA sequences that can make copies of themselves and jump to different places in your genome.
description.level5: Long stretches of DNA that can duplicate themselves and insert the copy elsewhere in the genome.
description.level6: Long Interspersed Nuclear Elements (LINEs) are autonomous retrotransposons capable of self-replication.
description.level7: LINEs are class I transposable elements that replicate through an RNA intermediate using reverse transcriptase.
description.level8: LINE elements, particularly LINE-1, are autonomous non-LTR retrotransposons constituting ~17% of the human genome with ongoing activity.

description.level3: Tiny pieces of DNA that copied themselves over a million times!
description.level4: Small bits of DNA that have duplicated themselves over and over, appearing more than a million times.
description.level5: Short DNA sequences that have proliferated to over a million copies throughout the human genome.
description.level6: SINEs (Short Interspersed Nuclear Elements) like Alu are non-autonomous elements that hijack LINE machinery to copy themselves.
description.level7: Alu elements are primate-specific SINEs that depend on LINE-1 proteins for retrotransposition, numbering over 1 million copies.
description.level8: Alu elements are ~300bp non-autonomous retrotransposons comprising ~11% of the genome, retrotranspositionally active via LINE-1 machinery.

description.level3: Broken copies of genes that don't work anymore, like fossils in your DNA.
description.level4: Old copies of genes that have broken down over time and no longer make proteins.
description.level5: Non-functional copies of genes that accumulated mutations and can no longer produce working proteins.
description.level6: Pseudogenes are defunct relatives of functional genes that have lost their protein-coding ability through mutations.
description.level7: Pseudogenes arise through duplication or retrotransposition and accumulate disabling mutations while preserving sequence similarity to parent genes.
description.level8: Pseudogenes are genomic sequences with homology to functional genes but rendered non-functional by frameshift mutations, premature stops, or regulatory defects.

description.level3: DNA pieces that used to be able to cut themselves out and paste somewhere else.
description.level4: Ancient DNA sequences that could move around by cutting themselves out and inserting elsewhere.
description.level5: DNA transposons that historically moved via a cut-and-paste mechanism, though most are now inactive.
description.level6: DNA transposons are Class II transposable elements that mobilized via transposase-mediated excision and reinsertion.
description.level7: DNA transposons moved through a conservative cut-and-paste mechanism, unlike retrotransposons' replicative copy-and-paste method.
description.level8: DNA transposons constitute ~3% of the genome, mobilizing via transposase enzymes, though all human copies became inactive ~37 MYA.

shortDescription.level3: An old virus gene that helps babies grow inside their moms!
shortDescription.level4: A gene from an ancient virus that now helps connect babies to their mothers during pregnancy.
shortDescription.level5: A former viral gene that evolved to help form the placenta, connecting mother and baby.
shortDescription.level6: An endogenous retroviral envelope gene co-opted for placental syncytiotrophoblast fusion.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-W derived Syncytin-1 mediates cell-cell fusion in placental development, demonstrating viral domestication.
shortDescription.level8: Syncytin-1 (ERVW-1) is a fusogenic envelope protein derived from HERV-W, essential for syncytiotrophoblast formation.

funFact.level3: Without this old virus, mammals might not be able to have babies the way we do!
funFact.level4: This virus DNA was captured about 25 million years ago and became essential for pregnancy!
funFact.level5: We essentially repurposed a virus infection to help with pregnancy - talk about making lemonade from lemons!
funFact.level6: Syncytin-1 demonstrates exaptation: a viral gene repurposed for essential host function.
funFact.level7: Multiple mammals independently captured different retroviral envelopes for placentation - convergent evolution at its finest.
funFact.level8: Syncytins represent one of the clearest examples of retroviral domestication across mammalian evolution.

shortDescription.level3: Another virus gene that helps with having babies.
shortDescription.level4: A second viral gene that helps protect babies in the womb.
shortDescription.level5: Another domesticated viral gene involved in placental development and immune protection.
shortDescription.level6: A second retroviral envelope gene with immunosuppressive and fusogenic functions in the placenta.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-FRD derived Syncytin-2 has both fusogenic and immunosuppressive properties for fetomaternal tolerance.
shortDescription.level8: Syncytin-2 (ERVFRD-1) provides both cell fusion capability and immunomodulatory function at the maternal-fetal interface.

features.name: HERV-K (HML-2)

shortDescription.level3: The most recent virus that got stuck in human DNA - only about 200,000 years ago!
shortDescription.level4: The newest virus DNA in humans, inserted around the time modern humans appeared.
shortDescription.level5: The most recently active human endogenous retrovirus, with some copies still potentially active.
shortDescription.level6: HERV-K HML-2 represents the youngest HERV family with human-specific insertions and residual coding capacity.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-K (HML-2) is the only HERV family with human-specific members, some retaining open reading frames.
shortDescription.level8: HERV-K HML-2 elements include human-specific proviruses with intact ORFs, suggesting recent (<1MYA) and possibly ongoing activity.

funFact.level3: Some scientists think this virus might still be able to wake up!
funFact.level4: This is so young (for virus DNA) that different people have different copies!
funFact.level5: HERV-K is polymorphic - meaning some people have copies that others don't!
funFact.level6: Some HERV-K insertions are present in only some humans, indicating very recent integration.
funFact.level7: HERV-K polymorphism and potential somatic activity make it unique among human ERVs.
funFact.level8: HERV-K HML-2 shows human-specific polymorphic insertions and evidence of somatic activity in certain pathological conditions.

features.functionKnown: Unknown, possibly involved in some diseases

features.name: Active LINE-1

shortDescription.level3: A piece of DNA that can still copy itself and move around!
shortDescription.level4: One of about 100 LINE-1 elements that can still actively jump around in your genome.
shortDescription.level5: An active retrotransposon that continues to make new copies of itself in human cells.
shortDescription.level6: A full-length, retrotranspositionally competent LINE-1 element with intact ORFs.
shortDescription.level7: Active L1HS elements retain functional ORF1p and ORF2p for autonomous retrotransposition.
shortDescription.level8: This full-length L1HS element (~6kb) contains intact ORF1 (RNA chaperone) and ORF2 (RT/EN) for autonomous mobilization.

funFact.level3: These jumping genes are still making new copies in your cells right now!
funFact.level4: Out of 500,000 LINE-1 copies, only about 100 can still jump - but they do!
funFact.level5: LINE-1 elements cause about 1 in every 250 disease-causing mutations in humans.
funFact.level6: Active LINE-1s contribute to somatic mosaicism and can cause insertional mutagenesis.
funFact.level7: L1 retrotransposition generates ~80-100 novel insertions per individual per generation.
funFact.level8: Active L1 elements drive ongoing genomic evolution, contributing to structural variation and disease mutations.

features.functionKnown: Creates genomic diversity, sometimes causes disease

shortDescription.level3: A jumping gene that landed in the wrong spot and causes a blood disease.
shortDescription.level4: A LINE-1 that jumped into an important gene and caused the first known disease from a jumping gene.
shortDescription.level5: The first documented case of a transposon insertion causing human disease - hemophilia A.
shortDescription.level6: A LINE-1 insertion in the Factor VIII gene, the first identified retrotransposon-mediated human disease.
shortDescription.level7: This L1 insertion in F8 intron 14 was the first demonstration of L1 retrotransposition causing human genetic disease.
shortDescription.level8: The F8 L1 insertion (1988) established L1 as an active mutagen, disrupting Factor VIII expression and causing hemophilia A.

features.name: BRCA1 Alu Cluster

shortDescription.level3: A bunch of copied DNA bits that sometimes cause mix-ups in an important cancer gene.
shortDescription.level4: Many Alu copies clustered together that can cause errors when DNA is copied.
shortDescription.level5: A region dense with Alu elements that promotes harmful recombination in the BRCA1 gene.
shortDescription.level6: An Alu-rich region in BRCA1 that facilitates pathogenic Alu-mediated deletions and duplications.
shortDescription.level7: The high Alu density in BRCA1 (~40% of gene) predisposes to non-allelic homologous recombination events.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1's exceptionally high Alu content drives Alu-Alu mediated rearrangements, accounting for ~10% of pathogenic variants.

features.functionKnown: Causes genomic instability, contributes to BRCA1 mutations

shortDescription.level3: A copy-paste gene piece that's active in brain cells.
shortDescription.level4: An Alu element that can still jump around, especially in brain cells.
shortDescription.level5: An active Alu element that retrotransposes in neural progenitor cells, contributing to brain diversity.
shortDescription.level6: Alu elements show increased retrotransposition in neural progenitors, creating somatic mosaicism.
shortDescription.level7: L1/Alu activity in neural progenitor cells generates somatic insertions contributing to neuronal diversity.
shortDescription.level8: Somatic retrotransposition of Alu elements in NPCs contributes to neuronal genome mosaicism and potentially neural diversity.

funFact.level3: Your brain cells might each have slightly different DNA because of jumping genes!
funFact.level4: Jumping genes are more active in brain cells, making each neuron slightly unique!
funFact.level5: L1 and Alu activity in the brain means your neurons aren't all genetically identical.
funFact.level6: Somatic retrotransposition creates neuronal mosaicism - each brain cell may have unique insertions.
funFact.level7: Neural retrotransposition may contribute to neural circuit diversity and plasticity.
funFact.level8: Elevated L1/Alu somatic activity in neurons may contribute to neural diversity, though functional significance remains debated.

shortDescription.level3: Old smell genes that stopped working when our ancestors started using their eyes more.
shortDescription.level4: Broken copies of smell genes - we lost many when vision became more important.
shortDescription.level5: A cluster of non-functional olfactory receptor genes, remnants of our more smell-dependent ancestors.
shortDescription.level6: Olfactory receptor pseudogenes representing the decline of smell as humans evolved better color vision.
shortDescription.level7: The OR gene family shows massive pseudogenization (~60%) correlating with the evolution of trichromatic vision.
shortDescription.level8: Human olfactory receptor pseudogenes reflect relaxed selection following trichromacy acquisition and olfaction's reduced fitness contribution.

funFact.level3: Dogs have way fewer broken smell genes, which is why their noses are so much better!
funFact.level4: We have about 400 working smell genes but over 600 broken ones!
funFact.level5: Humans have ~400 functional OR genes but ~600 pseudogenes - dogs have far fewer pseudogenes!
funFact.level6: The human OR repertoire is ~40% functional vs ~80% in dogs, reflecting our visual vs olfactory lifestyle.
funFact.level7: OR pseudogenization accelerated in the catarrhine lineage coincident with full trichromacy evolution.
funFact.level8: Comparative genomics reveals OR pseudogenization rates correlate inversely with olfactory dependence across mammals.

shortDescription.level3: A broken gene that means humans can't make their own Vitamin C!
shortDescription.level4: The reason we need to eat fruits and vegetables - this gene broke millions of years ago.
shortDescription.level5: A non-functional vitamin C synthesis gene, explaining why humans require dietary vitamin C.
shortDescription.level6: GULOP pseudogene lost function ~40 MYA, making vitamin C an essential dietary nutrient for primates.
shortDescription.level7: The GULO pseudogene contains multiple disabling mutations shared with other simian primates.
shortDescription.level8: GULOP (L-gulonolactone oxidase pseudogene) carries shared-derived mutations establishing vitamin C auxotrophy in Haplorrhini.

funFact.level3: Most animals make their own Vitamin C, but we have to eat it because this gene broke!
funFact.level4: Sailors used to get sick (scurvy) because they didn't know they needed vitamin C - blame this gene!
funFact.level5: This broken gene is why scurvy plagued sailors - we can't synthesize vitamin C like most mammals.
funFact.level6: Guinea pigs independently broke their GULO gene, making them useful scurvy research models.
funFact.level7: GULO pseudogenization occurred independently in guinea pigs, some bats, and passerine birds.
funFact.level8: Multiple independent GULO losses across mammals demonstrate parallel evolution under fruit-rich dietary conditions.

shortDescription.level3: Broken egg-making genes from when our ancient ancestors laid eggs!
shortDescription.level4: Leftover genes from egg-laying ancestors - proof that mammals evolved from egg-layers.
shortDescription.level5: Remnants of vitellogenin genes used by our egg-laying ancestors, replaced by lactation.
shortDescription.level6: Vitellogenin pseudogenes trace mammalian evolution from oviparity to viviparity and lactation.
shortDescription.level7: VIT pseudogenization correlates temporally with casein gene expansion during lactation evolution.
shortDescription.level8: Human vitellogenin pseudogenes show stepwise inactivation coinciding with casein gene family expansion ~100-300 MYA.

funFact.level3: We still have broken egg genes because we evolved from animals that laid eggs!
funFact.level4: When mammals evolved to make milk, we didn't need egg yolk genes anymore - but they're still there, broken!
funFact.level5: The vitellogenin genes broke as casein (milk protein) genes evolved - we traded eggs for milk!
funFact.level6: Vitellogenin loss and casein emergence show clear evolutionary tradeoff timing.
funFact.level7: The VIT/casein evolutionary transition is a textbook example of gene family replacement.
funFact.level8: VIT pseudogenization dates align with casein gene family radiation, demonstrating molecular basis for oviparity-viviparity transition.

shortDescription.level3: An ancient jumping gene that stopped jumping millions of years ago.
shortDescription.level4: A cut-and-paste gene that was active in our distant ancestors but is now a DNA fossil.
shortDescription.level5: A DNA transposon that was active in early mammals but became immobile ~37 million years ago.
shortDescription.level6: A hAT-superfamily DNA transposon, part of the Charlie/MER family inactive since ~37 MYA.
shortDescription.level7: Charlie elements are non-autonomous hAT derivatives that mobilized via ancestral autonomous copies.
shortDescription.level8: Charlie family elements represent MITEs derived from hAT-family transposons, with activity ceasing in the primate lineage.

shortDescription.level3: A virus gene that became super important for making memories!
shortDescription.level4: An ancient virus gene that your brain uses to form and store memories.
shortDescription.level5: A gene derived from a retrotransposon that's essential for memory formation in the brain.
shortDescription.level6: Arc encodes a Gag-like protein that forms capsid-like structures for intercellular mRNA transport.
shortDescription.level7: Arc protein assembles into virus-like capsids that transfer mRNA between neurons for synaptic plasticity.
shortDescription.level8: Arc represents an exapted Ty3/Gypsy Gag protein that forms capsid-like particles mediating intercellular mRNA transfer at synapses.

funFact.level3: This virus gene helps your brain cells talk to each other to make memories!
funFact.level4: Arc protein actually makes little virus-like shells to send messages between brain cells!
funFact.level5: Arc makes capsid-like structures (like virus shells) to transport RNA between neurons!
funFact.level6: Arc represents a striking example of viral gene domestication for neural function.
funFact.level7: Arc's virus-like mRNA delivery mechanism suggests retroviral exaptation for neural circuit function.
funFact.level8: Arc exemplifies molecular domestication where Gag's capsid-forming ability was repurposed for synaptic plasticity.

shortDescription.level3: A muscle gene that broke, letting our heads get bigger for bigger brains!
shortDescription.level4: A jaw muscle gene that stopped working, possibly letting human skulls grow larger.
shortDescription.level5: A myosin gene inactivated ~2.4 MYA, coinciding with brain expansion in human evolution.
shortDescription.level6: MYH16 pseudogenization may have relaxed constraints on skull size, facilitating encephalization.
shortDescription.level7: The MYH16 inactivating mutation (~2.4 MYA) correlates with reduced masticatory musculature and cranial expansion.
shortDescription.level8: MYH16 carries a 2-bp deletion creating a frameshift, dated to ~2.4 MYA coincident with Homo brain expansion.

funFact.level3: Some scientists think breaking this gene helped humans grow bigger brains!
funFact.level4: Weaker jaw muscles might have let our skulls grow bigger to fit larger brains!
funFact.level5: The timing of this gene breaking matches perfectly with when human brains started getting bigger!
funFact.level6: This hypothesis links masticatory muscle reduction to relaxed cranial constraint.
funFact.level7: While correlation is striking, causation between MYH16 loss and encephalization remains debated.
funFact.level8: The MYH16-encephalization hypothesis remains controversial, though temporal correlation is notable.

shortDescription.level3: Special markers that help turn off one X chromosome in girls.
shortDescription.level4: LINE elements that help silence one X chromosome in females, so they don't have double the genes.
shortDescription.level5: LINE-1 elements enriched on the X chromosome that may facilitate X-inactivation spreading.
shortDescription.level6: X-chromosome LINE density correlates with X-inactivation efficiency, possibly serving as way stations.
shortDescription.level7: Lyon's 'way station' hypothesis suggests LINEs propagate heterochromatin during X-inactivation.
shortDescription.level8: X-chromosome L1 enrichment (~30% vs ~17% autosomal) may facilitate XIST-mediated silencing propagation.

funFact.level3: Girls have two X chromosomes but only use one - these DNA bits help pick which one!
funFact.level4: The X chromosome has almost twice as many LINE elements as other chromosomes!
funFact.level5: The X chromosome is 30% LINEs (vs 17% elsewhere) - this may help with X-inactivation!
funFact.level6: The 2-fold LINE enrichment on X chromosomes is a striking genomic feature with functional implications.
funFact.level7: X-linked LINE enrichment is conserved across mammals, supporting functional significance.
funFact.level8: Lyon's way-station hypothesis for LINE-mediated X-inactivation spreading remains supported by genomic and functional data.

shortDescription.level3: Old virus bits that help train our immune system!
shortDescription.level4: HERV sequences that evolved to help regulate how our immune system works.
shortDescription.level5: Endogenous retroviruses co-opted for interferon response and immune regulation.
shortDescription.level6: Multiple HERV-derived sequences serve as interferon-stimulated enhancers and immune regulators.
shortDescription.level7: ERV-derived sequences constitute a significant fraction of primate-specific interferon response elements.
shortDescription.level8: HERV LTRs provide species-specific cis-regulatory elements for innate immunity genes, particularly in interferon pathways.

funFact.level3: These old viruses now help us fight new viruses - they switched sides!
funFact.level4: Ancient viruses that once tried to infect us now help our immune system fight other infections!
funFact.level5: ERVs contribute many regulatory elements to our immune response - former enemies turned allies!
funFact.level6: About 20% of human interferon response elements derive from endogenous retroviruses.
funFact.level7: ERV-derived regulatory elements show species-specific immune response patterns.
funFact.level8: ERV domestication for innate immunity represents ongoing host-virus co-evolution with functional consequences.

shortDescription.level3: Broken taste genes that used to help us detect more bitter things.
shortDescription.level4: Non-working bitter taste receptor genes, showing we've lost some taste sensitivity.
shortDescription.level5: Pseudogenized bitter taste receptors reflecting dietary changes in human evolution.
shortDescription.level6: TAS2R pseudogenes represent relaxed selection on bitter detection as diet shifted.
shortDescription.level7: Human TAS2R pseudogenization varies by population, reflecting local dietary adaptation.
shortDescription.level8: TAS2R pseudogene variation shows population-specific patterns correlating with historical dietary toxin exposure.

funFact.level3: Different people have different broken taste genes, so we all taste things a bit differently!
funFact.level4: Some bitter taste genes are broken in some people but not others - that's why we like different foods!
funFact.level5: TAS2R gene variation explains why some people hate Brussels sprouts while others love them!
funFact.level6: TAS2R variation contributes to individual differences in bitter food preferences.
funFact.level7: Population-specific TAS2R pseudogenization patterns reflect local dietary selective pressures.
funFact.level8: TAS2R copy number and pseudogenization variation represents ongoing neutral evolution and dietary adaptation.

shortDescription.level3: Special repeating DNA that holds chromosomes together when cells divide.
shortDescription.level4: Highly repetitive DNA at chromosome centers essential for cell division.
shortDescription.level5: Alpha satellite DNA at centromeres that enables proper chromosome segregation during cell division.
shortDescription.level6: Centromeric alpha satellite arrays provide the foundation for kinetochore assembly.
shortDescription.level7: Alpha satellite higher-order repeats (HORs) establish centromere identity through CENP-A nucleosome positioning.
shortDescription.level8: Alpha satellite HOR arrays are essential for centromere function, kinetochore assembly, and accurate chromosome segregation.

funFact.level3: These are the parts that hold your chromosomes in the middle!
funFact.level4: Without this repeating DNA, your chromosomes would get lost when cells divide!
funFact.level5: Centromeric DNA is so repetitive that it was excluded from the 'completed' human genome until 2022!
funFact.level6: The T2T consortium finally sequenced centromeric regions in 2022, completing the human genome.
funFact.level7: Centromeric alpha satellites remained as gaps in GRCh38 until the T2T-CHM13 assembly.
funFact.level8: Complete centromeric sequence assembly required specialized long-read technologies due to repeat complexity.

features.name: Telomeric Repeats

shortDescription.level3: Special caps on the ends of chromosomes, like the plastic tips on shoelaces.
shortDescription.level4: Protective repeating sequences at chromosome ends that prevent DNA damage.
shortDescription.level5: TTAGGG repeats at chromosome ends that protect DNA and shorten with each cell division.
shortDescription.level6: Telomeric repeats protect chromosome ends and shorten progressively, limiting replicative lifespan.
shortDescription.level7: Telomere attrition serves as a mitotic clock; critically short telomeres trigger senescence or apoptosis.
shortDescription.level8: Telomeric (TTAGGG)n arrays protect chromosome termini; progressive shortening underlies replicative senescence and is counteracted by telomerase in stem/cancer cells.

funFact.level3: These get shorter every time your cells divide - they're like a countdown clock!
funFact.level4: Your telomeres shorten as you age, which is why scientists study them in aging research.
funFact.level5: Telomere length is linked to aging - some jellyfish stay young by constantly rebuilding theirs!
funFact.level6: Telomere biology won the 2009 Nobel Prize and is central to cancer and aging research.
funFact.level7: Telomerase reactivation is a hallmark of cancer; telomere maintenance is essential for immortalization.
funFact.level8: Telomere biology bridges replicative senescence, stem cell function, aging, and oncogenesis.

features.functionKnown: Essential for chromosome stability and aging

shortDescription.level3: Alu pieces that let your cells edit messages in your RNA!
shortDescription.level4: Inverted Alu pairs that enable cells to change RNA messages after they're made.
shortDescription.level5: Alu elements in inverted orientation that create RNA structures subject to A-to-I editing.
shortDescription.level6: Inverted Alu pairs form dsRNA structures extensively edited by ADAR enzymes.
shortDescription.level7: Alu-derived dsRNA is the primary substrate for ADAR A-to-I editing in the human transcriptome.
shortDescription.level8: Primate-specific Alu-mediated A-to-I editing shapes the transcriptome and innate immune dsRNA recognition.

funFact.level3: Your cells can change the messages in RNA - Alu elements make this possible!
funFact.level4: More than 100 million spots in your RNA can be edited, mostly thanks to Alu elements!
funFact.level5: Humans have millions of A-to-I RNA editing sites, mostly in Alu - more than any other mammal!
funFact.level6: The human editome contains >100 million A-to-I sites, vastly exceeding other mammals.
funFact.level7: Alu-mediated expansion of the editome may contribute to human-specific neural complexity.
funFact.level8: Massive Alu-dependent editome expansion in primates may contribute to neural transcriptome complexity and cognitive evolution.

shortDescription.level3: An extra backup copy of an important gene that can help if the main one breaks.
shortDescription.level4: A duplicated region containing SMN genes - having backups can protect against disease.
shortDescription.level5: The SMN1/SMN2 duplication where SMN2 copy number modifies spinal muscular atrophy severity.
shortDescription.level6: Segmental duplication created SMN1/SMN2; SMN2 copy number is a key SMA severity modifier.
shortDescription.level7: SMN2's partial functional redundancy with SMN1 underlies SMA pathogenesis and antisense oligo therapy rationale.
shortDescription.level8: The SMN1/SMN2 segmental duplication illustrates how paralog redundancy modifies disease phenotypes and enables novel therapeutic strategies.

funFact.level3: The backup copy (SMN2) is why gene therapy for SMA works!
funFact.level4: Doctors can now use the backup SMN2 gene to help treat spinal muscular atrophy!
funFact.level5: SMN2 copy number varies between people and directly affects SMA disease severity.
funFact.level6: SMN2-targeted therapies (nusinersen, risdiplam) exploit this segmental duplication for treatment.
funFact.level7: The SMN locus exemplifies translational genomics: understanding duplication biology enabled therapy.
funFact.level8: SMN2-directed therapeutics (splice modulators, gene replacement) represent precision medicine enabled by segmental duplication biology.
